definitions.definition: an amount of something that has been cut or separated from the rest of it; a standard amount of something

examples.text: She wrote something on a small **piece of paper**.
a piece of wood/metal
a large **piece of land**
a **piece of cake**
a piece of cheese/meat/bread
I've got a piece of grit in my eye.
a small/little/tiny piece of something
He cut the pizza into bite-sized pieces.
She makes her sculptures out of odd pieces of scrap metal.
She tore the letter into tiny pieces.

definitions.definition: one of the bits or parts that something breaks into
definitions.sensetop: piece of somethingto pieces in pieces

examples.text: There were tiny pieces of glass all over the road.
The boat had been smashed to pieces on the rocks.
The building was **blown to pieces**.
tear/rip something to pieces
The vase lay in pieces on the floor.
The cake just broke into pieces when I cut it.
The plate smashed into little pieces on the stone floor.
The vase was now in pieces on the kitchen floor.

definitions.definition: one of the parts that something is made of

examples.text: He **took** the clock **to pieces**.
a missing piece of the puzzle
The bridge was taken down **piece by piece**.
She's been doing a 500-piece jigsaw.
Can I take this jigsaw to pieces?
I had to take the car to pieces in order to repair it.
A few pieces of the puzzle were missing.
This chair comes to pieces.
We'll need to take the engine apart, piece by piece.
He broke the clock down into pieces.
There had to be some missing piece of the story.

definitions.definition: a single item of a particular type, especially one that forms part of a set

examples.text: a **piece of equipment/furniture**
a piece of clothing/luggage
a piece of machinery
a 28-piece dinner service

definitions.definition: used with many uncountable nouns to describe a single example or an amount of something

examples.text: a **piece of information/evidence/advice/news/legislation**
a **piece of software**
This is a superb **piece of work**.
It was an interesting piece of research.
The building is a **piece of history** *(= of historical interest or importance)*.
Isn't that a piece of luck?
You should eat at least two pieces of fruit a day.

definitions.definition: a single item of writing, art, music, etc. that somebody has produced or created; a short item of writing from a longer work

examples.text: a **piece of music/art**
a fine **piece of writing**
They performed pieces by Bach and Handel.
The painting is a **companion piece** to *(= is closely related to and intended to be displayed with)* an earlier work.
They have some beautiful pieces *(= works of art, etc.)* in their home.
She read a piece from ‘Alice in Wonderland’.
The orchestra performed pieces by Ravel and Prokofiev.
Auditioning students are required to play a solo piece of their choice.
a piece for symphony orchestra, choir and four soloists
He hasn't produced a single piece of writing this year.
They are exhibiting two important pieces by Calder.
This is an effective piece of writing.
a companion piece to the portrait of Gauguin's empty chair
The best pieces include three paintings by El Greco.

definitions.definition: an article in a newspaper or magazine or a broadcast on television or radio

examples.text: The Washington Post ran a series of **opinion pieces** criticizing the policy.
Did you see her piece about the internet in the paper today?
a short piece by Will Simons on television satire
an occasional piece on the lives of ordinary people
an original piece written specifically for the producer

definitions.definition: a coin of the value mentioned

examples.text: a 50p piece
a five-cent piece

definitions.definition: one of the small figures or objects that you move around in games such as chess
a part or share of something

examples.text: companies seeking a piece of the market

definitions.definition: a gun
a short distance

examples.text: She lives down the road a piece from here.

definitions.definition: small objects or items of various kinds

examples.text: She stuffed all her bits and pieces into a bag and left.
I just need to get a few bits and pieces at the supermarket.

definitions.definition: to use bombs or other weapons to destroy somebody/something completely

examples.text: The plane was blown to pieces when the bomb exploded.

definitions.definition: to become very old and in bad condition because of long use

examples.text: Our car is falling to pieces, we've had it so long.
My old dictionary is falling to pieces.

definitions.definition: to stop working; to be destroyed

examples.text: He's worried the business will fall to pieces without him.

definitions.definition: to tell somebody that you think their behaviour is bad or are angry with them
to be so upset or afraid that you cannot manage to live or work normally

examples.text: After his wife died he just went to pieces.

definitions.definition: used to say that there is no definite answer to a question

examples.text: ‘How long will it take?’ ‘How long's a piece of string?’

definitions.definition: safe; not damaged or hurt, especially after a journey or dangerous experience

examples.text: They were lucky to get home in one piece.

definitions.definition: a person who is unpleasant, unkind or dishonest

examples.text: Don’t trust him; he’s a nasty piece of work.
He's a thoroughly nasty piece of work.

definitions.definition: all the same or similar

examples.text: The houses are all of a piece.

definitions.definition: all at the same time

examples.text: The house was built all of a piece in 1754.

definitions.definition: to criticize somebody, or their work or ideas, very severely
to return or to help somebody return to a normal situation, particularly after a shock or a disaster

examples.text: You cannot live your children's lives for them; you can only be there to pick up the pieces when things go wrong.

definitions.definition: a thing that is very easy to do
a share of the available money or benefits that you believe you have a right to

examples.text: The company is demanding a larger slice of the corporate pie.

definitions.definition: a thing that is very easy to do
used to express the fact that you admire somebody or find them funny, often when they have done something that surprises you

examples.text: You're some piece of work, Jack, do you know that?

definitions.definition: a share or role in an interesting or exciting activity, especially one that makes money

examples.text: Foreign firms will all want a piece of the action if the new airport goes ahead.

definitions.definition: to say exactly what you feel or think
the person or thing that is responsible for all the trouble in a situation

examples.text: It’s hard to identify the real villain of the piece in this case.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French piece (compare with medieval Latin pecia, petium), of obscure ultimate origin.
